ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned PCR, AGE, Primer Design, DNA purification, and cloning.
The course reinforced my ability to conduct procedures that are particularly useful in molecular biology research, such as CRISPR, PCR, cloning etc.
Molecular biology techniques including gel electrophoresis, PCR, crispr/cas9, and plasmid building. Work on scientific writing, inventory records, and keeping laboratory database.
I learned how to do PCR, agarose gel electrophoresis, and other methods important for molecular biology. I also learned how to keep lab entries on Benchling.

I learned a great deal about molecular biology while also gaining many practical skills. I learned how to do PCR, cloning, gene research, and basic CRISPR experiments. I also learned how to write a scientific paper.

This course is a very good introduction to techniques and laboratory practice in a molecular biology lab. I gained familiarity with widely used protocols while working on a semester-long project and learned the basics of writing a research paper, although I definitely think I learned more about actual experimentation than writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: you get thrown in the deep end which is bad. but you learn a lot which is good.

The class is designed as a coherent, semester-long research project on genes of unknown functions. This design is very innovative and somewhat resembles the workflow of a real research project.
However, the labs could have been more efficient, since there was a large amount of waiting in each lab session. It was not infrequent that the lab ran over 4hrs.
Very interactive course focused on a singular project throughout the course. It could be a little disorganized at times, but that's also the nature of lab work.

Strengths: Professor Moreno is a great Professor and the TAs were also really good in helping students understand what to do for the lab.
Weaknesses: We never had any formal syllabus with the assignments we needed to do. This would have helped me organize my time and create a timeline for the course but at the same time Professor Moreno was mindful with the deadlines so this was not a big problem!

It would be nice if Professor Moreno would have taken more time to explain the science behind the protocols and reagents we were using because many times no one understood what we were using which made the class less enjoyable.

This course was a great introduction to working in a molecular biology lab and I think techniques were taught well. I think it could be improved by spending more time to make sure we really understood the background of the project we were working on and how to improve our scientific writing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Good biology lab and Dr. Moreno is great!
Yes. Professor Moreno is an amazing professor and you learn a lot of skills that will help you when getting started on research.
If you want to do research in the biological sciences, absolutely! You'll learn so much!

I would recommend this course to any student who wants to do research in biology and hasn't been in a lab before. Having recently started working in a lab, I've been using almost all of the same techniques I learned in this course which has made me much more comfortable. I somewhat lost interest in the specific research topic we were studying (blossom-end rot disease in tomatoes), which may be why I did not enjoy writing the research paper, but I think it did teach me some useful scientific writing skills.
